text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani newspapers on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
THE MUSLIM

- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has said his government will restore and "ideal" law and order situation in Pakistan in the next few months by publicly hanging terrorists without caring for objections from so-called human rights organisations.

- Senate (upper house) chairman Wasim Sajjad rejected a petition of opposition leader Benazir Bhutto to summon her jailed husband to the house so he could take oath as a Senate member, to which position he was elected in March.

- The Prime Minister's Accountability Cell has prepared references against former Privatisation Commission chairman Naveed Qamar and seven others officials for alleged irregularities in the sale of Makarwal coal mines.
THE NATION
- The opposition Pakistan People's Party has rejected the newly passed Anti-Terrorist Bill as an attempt by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's government to perpetuate a totalitarian rule.
- Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz has said that the government was neither devaluing the rupee nor there was any proposal to increase electricity tariffs.
- Tehrik-I-Insaaf (justice movement) leader and former cricketer Imran Khan has described the "Sita White scandal" as a political move initiated against him during the election campaign.

- The Capital Development Authority has served a notice on Prince Karim Aga Khan, head of the Ismaili community, for not undertaking construction of a five-star hotel on a plot alloted to him in Islamabad.
THE NEWS

- The U.S.- Pakistan Consultative Group will meet in Washington on October 15-16 to discuss a number of bilateral issues, including reimbursement of payments made to the United States for F-16 aircraft, which Washington has refused to supply under the so-called Pressler Amendment law.
DAWN
- Commerce Minister Ishaq Dar has said collection of 3.0 percent general sales tax on retail items would start on January 1, 1998.
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has asked Washington to stop pressurising Pakistan on the nuclear issue.
- The Anti-terrorism Bill was challenged in the Lahore High Court on the ground that it was in violation of the fundamental rights guaranteed under Pakistan's constitution.
- President Bill Clinton hopes to visit Pakistan, U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said on Friday.
- The government has withdrawn its decision to scrap the 1,320-mw power project of Consolidated Electric Power Asia to be constructed at Keti Bunder.
- The Allied Bank of Pakistan plans to close down nearly 50 unprofitable branches to whittle down its expenditure and improve performance.
- South Korean trade organisations are keen to hold industry-specific conferences in different fields so that Korean investment could be attracted to Pakistan.
BUSINESS RECORDER
- Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz has hinted that country's foreign exchange reserves have crossed the barrier of $1.5 billion mark.
- The Pakistani government is considering to review the power policy to ensure that consumers are not overburderned by high tariffs.
